Posts.Content: I've had quite a few transfusions - completely painless (though if you need a cannula you'll have to have a needle put in) and not uncomfortable at all.  I've never felt the blood going in or anything (it goes in more slowly than other fluids, so you may be less likely to feel it as a result).  I've tended to feel brighter within a day or so of the transfusion.  The biggest downside is boredom - it would take 4-5hrs for me to get 2 units, so bring some food and something to keep you entertained! It's a very safe procedure nowadays, but ask about any concerns on Monday.  You'll probably be asked to keep an eye out for any signs of an allergic reaction (e.g. a rash). I don't much like the sight of blood going into me myself, but just try not to look at the bag...  Think I remember someone covering the bag up, which you could try if you really don't like the sight of the stuff.  If it helps, blood is quite a distinctive red colour - definitely looks quite different from Daunorubicin, though don't know about epirubicin.

Posts.Title: Given all clear.........but

Posts.Content: Definitely worth giving Macmillan a ring.  You're also entitled to ask for a second opinion, if you want to see if another oncologist would make the same recommendation (I think you should be able to see someone in another NHS trust, if you're concerned that your Trust is trying to keep costs down).  It's also quite reasonable to ask about the pros and cons of the recommended chemo as opposed to other regimes - the oncologist's recommendation might be absolutely the right thing for you, but her or a colleague should be able to explain why they believe it to be the best option. The effect on fertility is something that it's quite reasonable to consider when deciding what treatment to have (I don't have any kids, and the possibility of my being fertile after chemo was one reason why the treatment I've had was recommended over more intensive treatment).  It's very reasonable to have questions, though - I hope you can get the treatment that's right for you.

Posts.Content: Depends what you like doing to a fair extent.  You could try using a recumbent exercise bike or hand bike, or something like yoga/pilates. Weight training can be great for building up strength (you can start with light weights, or something like cans of baked beans, if you're needing to build up after your treatment). If you're struggling with the peripheral neuropathy, it might be worth seeing what a good gym can offer - cardio and weights machines might be helpful in doing a range of exercises.

Posts.Content: The flu jab can cause minor flu-like symptoms (e.g. being a bit achy).  Very worthwhile, though, to reduce the risk of getting flu while you're getting chemo.  Symptoms don't tend to last long, either. You can also look on it as a public-spirited thing to do, too :)  By being immunised yourself you're reducing the odds of passing on flu to the other people you come into contact with (inc. people getting chemo etc).

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear about the hot flushes.  If red clover isoflavones are effective for menopausal symptoms, it's because they have estrogen-like effects (while the tamoxifen is taken because it's an anti-estrogen drug).  I'd therefore be worried they might interfere with what the tamoxifen is trying to do.  Can you check with your oncologist, or call the Macmillan helpline, if you do want to try this? The possibility of red clover isoflavones interfering with tamoxifen is mentioned here http://umm.edu/health/medical/altmed/herb/red-clover

Posts.Content: Hospital staff shouldn't press their religion are you.  As well as being offensive to non-theists, they risk upsetting those with different faiths (non-Christians may not welcome conversations about Jesus) and fellow Christians (many religious people come from backgrounds where they wouldn't expect professionals to refer to God unless they were near the end...)  Can you speak to PALS about this?  It's quite inappropriate behaviour. I don't have any faith, but don't tend to be bothered about friends etc. saying they'll pray for me.  Not that I think it'll do anything, but it's a way of trying to show they care - when, often, there's not anything practical people can do.  And people often don't know the right thing to say - I've had people be far more tactless (and I'm sure I've been tactless with others myself!) so an offer of prayer isn't bad in the scheme of things :)  And - unless the person offering is being unhelpful - prayer doesn't need to be an alternative to more practical help.  Of course, if you do find this offensive, it's perfectly reasonable to ask people to stop offering to do this.

Posts.Content: I don't think Indole 3 Carbinol has been nearly extensively enough tested in humans to know what the side effects are - so if side effects are your concern, that's worth remembering.  I also don't think there's enough research to know whether or not Indole 3 Carbinol is effective in treating breast cancer - let alone whether it works as well as tamoxifen.  There can also be issues with quality of the manufacturing of dietary supplements -  which can make it hard to be confident that you're getting the doses you want of what you want. With tamoxifen, at least it's been widely enough tested that we know a lot more about the side effects.  We also know that tamoxifen is effective. Can you ask your oncologist for more information on the benefits and risks of tamoxifen?  This could give you better information on which to make your decision.

Posts.Content: Check with your doctor or nurse, but people getting cancer treatment definitely can have the flu vaccine - I have done. You will likely be advised to avoid live vaccines, but the standard flu vaccine doesn't contain any live virus - see here http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/flu-vaccine-questions-answers.aspx#causeflu  You may respond less well to the vaccine when getting chemo (so if you can have it before you start, that's a good idea) but it can still often be advised for chemo patients, as this benefits still often outweigh the risks by a good margin. Bottled mineral water is slightly more likely to contain bacteria that can make you ill than UK tap water (though this may not be a problem with carbonated water). This is a small risk - so I wouldn't panic if you've been drinking bottled water. Whether to avoid mineral water or not may depend on how low the chemo pushes your immunity - something to discuss with your doctor or nurse... Personally, I'd go for tap water as it's cheaper!  I know some people prefer bottled though. Some people don't get much mouth soreness and you can get soft heads for some electric toothbrushes.  It may be fine - I used an electric brush throughout chemo - though you may need to change to a manual.

Posts.Content: 0.8 may be low to start some chemos, but I wouldn't panic about admission or anything.  Worth being careful to avoid infections, but as long as they're above 0.5 doctors don't seem overly concerned.  My treatment could well keep neutrophils suppressed to around 0.8 level for a couple of years - and I'm going about things largely as normal. It's annoying when things are delayed, but very common.

Posts.Content: Could well be that the found some bacteria in your sample - it may then take them a little while to work out exactly what it is and what antibiotics treat it effectively.  I think that took a couple of days here. If you're worried, call your doctor tomorrow to ask about the results. It's quite plausible that they'll have found out it's a bacteria which you're taking the right antibiotics to treat, had thoughts to the effect of 'right, that's sorted' and then not bothered to tell you!

Posts.Content: Coot - don't panic.  Part of the reason there's more argument now about whether screening for breast cancer is a good idea is that treatments for cancer have got better (so even if cancers are caught later they can more often - though sadly not always - be treated effectively).  Chemo and surgery does bring risks, but - assuming any conventional treatment programme for DCIS - it's very unlikely that you'll die of an effect of the treatment, and even more unlikely that you'll die of the treatment any time soon.  The concern with overtreatment is more that of exposing lots of women to small but non-trivial risks, without them benefiting from the treatment. Debates about using mammograms in screening don't really relate to the way a mammogram was used in your diagnosis.  No-one sensible is saying that mammograms shouldn't be used as a diagnostic tool when there are symptoms or a lump is found (as in your case).  What is uncertain is whether or not using them to screen all women in certain age groups is useful.
Posts.Title: screening mammography

Posts.Content: Screening programmes do bring risks as well as benefits - mammography leads to treatment of women who would never have had problems caused by breast cancer in their lifetimes, and harms caused by treatment can be significant.  Some women will benefit from screening - with their cancer being detected while it's more treatable - although, counter-intuitively, as breast cancer treatment improves there may be less benefit to screening (more advanced cancer can be treated more effectively). The problem is that - when deciding whether or not to choose screening - people don't know which group they will fall into.  This means that it's important for the risks and benefits of screening to be communicated well to women who are deciding whether to get screened - I'm not convinced this happens in the NHS at the moment.
Posts.Title: screening mammography

Posts.Content: I'm sorry that so many of you have had breast cancer relatively young.  In terms of relevant stats, the latest Cochrane review of mammographies for screening is worth a look http://summaries.cochrane.org/CD001877/screening-for-breast-cancer-with-mammography As well as the difficulties with denser tissue in younger women, issues to think about with expanding the age group covered include: - If you include younger women who are less likely to get breast cancer, the false positive rate will be higher (because there are fewer true positives). E.g. if fewer women are diagnosed with cancer through screening (younger women are less likely to get cancer) but 10% of women don't have cancer are still called for additional testing, there will be more false positives for every accurate diagnosis. - If you screen older women, this is likely to lead to treatment of increasing numbers of women who wouldn't have become ill with or been killed by their cancer even if it had never been found. Although people are living longer we all die of something eventually, so a slow-growing cancer found when someone is 75 is a lot less likely to need treatment in their lifetime than one found when they're 40.
